Since you probably sleep in hostels and Bed & Breakfasts on the way, you don't need to carry as much supplies and gear (tents, sleeping bags) as when sleeping in the wild, however a sufficient supply of water and food for the day should be carried and you should always restock on first opportunity.
You should carry warm and waterproof clothes with you, a good map and travel guide and a compass.
A mobile phone is a good idea, but in remote areas there might be no coverage, so be warned.
Midges are a nuisance during summer months, so use a good insect repellent as well as sunscreen.

If you call ahead to book accommodation for the night, remember to cancel the booking if you don't want to stay there any more. If you don't show up, they might alarm the local rescue service thinking you are lost in the wild, although in fact you are sleeping at the place across the road.
